docs.lead_paragraph: Looking at the bright side, having 60 votes in the Senate could have been more trouble than it was worth. With one less vote, expectations might be more modest.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator-elect Scott Brown, Republican of Massachusetts, said in his victory speech that he was eager to get to Washington and start his new job. But Mr. Brown, who owes his victory to independent voters, will find himself at the center of a partisan typhoon over the fate of the major health care legislation. At his victory speech, the crowd chanted ''Forty-one! Forty-one! Forty-one!'' -- a reference to Mr. Brown's role as the 41st Republican senator, which will deny Democrats the 60 votes they need to overcome Republican filibusters and advance legislation, including the health care bill.
docs.abstract: Scott Brown's election brings number of Republicans in Senate to 41, denying Democrats 60 votes they need to overcome filibuster and advance health care overhaul legislation; Brown has said he will try to block that legislation and force Democrats to start over, but it might be politically risky for him to do so, given that he owes his election to independent voters and must face re-election in 2012 (M)
docs.snippet: Senator-elect Scott Brown, Republican of Massachusetts, said in his victory speech that he was eager to get to Washington and start his new job. But Mr. Brown, who owes his victory to independent voters, will find himself at the center of a partisan...

docs.lead_paragraph: Readers reacted Wednesday to news of Scott Brown's upset win in the Massachusetts Senate race. A sampling of their comments: ''Bay Staters shot themselves in the foot last night, as well as the rest of our fellow citizens, except we have the insurance to pay for our wounds. The rest of you in the other 49 states who have no insurance coverage, well, you'll have to limp.''Blueroses
docs.abstract: Readers react to news of Republican Scott Brown's upset win in Massachusetts Senate race and its likely impact in health care overhaul legislation (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama may have signaled some willingness to compromise on a scaled-back version of health care legislation, but the White House wants to be clear that the president's first preference is to pass the sort of far-reaching legislation that lawmakers and the administration were negotiating before the Republican victory in Massachusetts upended everything.

headline.main: White House: Obama Still Prefers a Major Overhaul

docs.abstract: President Obama still wants to pass far-reaching health care legislation, in part because many provisions are workable only in the context of a larger overhaul. But he may be willing to settle for less.
docs.snippet: President Obama still wants to pass far-reaching health care legislation, in part because many provisions are workable only in the context of a larger overhaul. But he may be willing to settle for less.
